clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Cessation Preferences of Menthol Smokers
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Cessation Preferences of Menthol Smokers

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Minnesota - Clinical and Translational Science Institute

clinical_study.source: University of Minnesota - Clinical and Translational Science Institute

brief_summary.textblock: The primary aim of this study is to determine menthol smokers' perception, product preference, and pattern of use across six products including, mint-flavored nicotine gum; non-flavored nicotine gum; mentholated nicotine inhaler; and non-menthol nicotine inhaler. Participants will undergo an orientation and baseline assessment followed by a 2-week product sampling phase. At the end of the 2 weeks of sampling, subjects will select a product to use during the following 2-week smoking cessation phase. This 2-week abstinence phase is followed by one week of abrupt withdrawal of the product. This study design was successfully used in a study we conducted that examined the smokers' preference for a variety or oral tobacco products.

primary_outcome.description: To determine menthol smokers' product perception and preference across 6 different types of products with varying mint content.

secondary_outcome.description: To determine menthol smokers' product perception and preference across 6 different types of products with varying nicotine content.

arm_group.description: All subjects will test six different nicotine replacement products over the course of the 2-week product sampling phase. The six nicotine replacement products being tested are non-flavored 2mg nicotine gum, non-flavored 4mg nicotine gum, mint-flavored 2mg nicotine gum, mint-flavored 4mg nicotine gum, non-flavored nicotine inhaler and mint-flavored inhaler. The order in which the subjects test these products will be randomized and subjects will be blinded to the nicotine content of the product but will be instructed about the flavor of the product.
